speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: Do not then walk too open.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: It doth not fit me. Hold, sir, here’s my purse.
In the south suburbs at the Elephant
Is best to lodge. I will bespeak our diet,
Whiles you beguile the time, and feed your knowledge
With viewing of the town. There shall you have me.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: Why I your purse?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Haply your eye shall light upon some toy
You have desire to purchase; and your store
I think is not for idle markets, sir.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: I’ll be your purse-bearer, and leave you
For an hour.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: To th’ Elephant.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: I do remember.

scene.scenepersonae: (Olivia, Maria, Malvolio, Servant, Toby, Fabian, Sir Andrew, Viola, Antonio, Officers)

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: I have sent after him; he says he’ll come.
How shall I feast him? What bestow of him?
For youth is bought more oft than begg’d or borrow’d.
I speak too loud.—
Where’s Malvolio? He is sad and civil,
And suits well for a servant with my fortunes.
Where is Malvolio?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: He’s coming, madam, but in very strange manner. He is sure possess’d, madam.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Why, what’s the matter? Does he rave?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: No, madam, he does nothing but smile. Your ladyship were best to have some guard about you, if he come, for sure the man is tainted in ’s wits.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Go call him hither.
I am as mad as he,
If sad and merry madness equal be.
How now, Malvolio?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Sweet lady, ho, ho.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Smil’st thou? I sent for thee upon a sad occasion.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Sad, lady? I could be sad. This does make some obstruction in the blood, this cross-gartering, but what of that? If it please the eye of one, it is with me as the very true sonnet is, “Please one, and please all.”

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Why, how dost thou, man? What is the matter with thee?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Not black in my mind, though yellow in my legs. It did come to his hands, and commands shall be executed.I think we do know the sweet Roman hand.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: To bed? Ay, sweet heart, and I’ll come to thee.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: God comfort thee! Why dost thou smile so, and kiss thy hand so oft?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: How do you, Malvolio?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: At your request! Yes, nightingales answer daws.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Why appear you with this ridiculous boldness before my lady?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: “Be not afraid of greatness”: ’twas well writ.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: What mean’st thou by that, Malvolio?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: “Some are born great”—

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Ha?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: “Some achieve greatness”—

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: What say’st thou?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: “And some have greatness thrust upon them.”

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Heaven restore thee!

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: “Remember who commended thy yellow stockings”—

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Thy yellow stockings?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: “And wish’d to see thee cross-garter’d.”

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Cross-garter’d?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: “Go to, thou art made, if thou desir’st to be so”—

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Am I made?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: “If not, let me see thee a servant still.”

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Why, this is very midsummer madness.

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: Madam, the young gentleman of the Count Orsino’s is return’d. I could hardly entreat him back. He attends your ladyship’s pleasure.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: I’ll come to him.
Good Maria, let this fellow be look’d to. Where’s my cousin Toby? Let some of my people have a special care of him. I would not have him miscarry for the half of my dowry.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: O ho, do you come near me now? No worse man than Sir Toby to look to me! This concurs directly with the letter: she sends him on purpose, that I may appear stubborn to him; for she incites me to that in the letter. “Cast thy humble slough,” says she; “be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants; let thy tongue tang with arguments of state; put thyself into the trick of singularity”; and consequently sets down the manner how: as a sad face, a reverend carriage, a slow tongue, in the habit of some sir of note, and so forth. I have lim’d her, but it is Jove’s doing, and Jove make me thankful! And when she went away now, “Let this fellow be look’d to”; “fellow”! Not “Malvolio,” nor after my degree, but “fellow.” Why, every thing adheres together, that no dram of a scruple, no scruple of a scruple, no obstacle, no incredulous or unsafe circumstance—What can be said? Nothing that can be can come between me and the full prospect of my hopes. Well, Jove, not I, is the doer of this, and he is to be thank’d.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Which way is he, in the name of sanctity? If all the devils of hell be drawn in little, and Legion himself possess’d him, yet I’ll speak to him.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Here he is, here he is. How is’t with you, sir?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: How is’t with you, man?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Go off, I discard you. Let me enjoy my private. Go off.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Lo, how hollow the fiend speaks within him! Did not I tell you? Sir Toby, my lady prays you to have a care of him.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Ah ha, does she so?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Go to, go to; peace, peace, we must deal gently with him. Let me alone. How do you, Malvolio? How is’t with you? What, man, defy the devil! Consider, he’s an enemy to mankind.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Do you know what you say?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: La you, and you speak ill of the devil, how he takes it at heart! Pray God he be not bewitch’d!

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Carry his water to th’ wise woman.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Marry, and it shall be done tomorrow morning if I live. My lady would not lose him for more than I’ll say.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: How now, mistress?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: O Lord!

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Prithee hold thy peace, this is not the way. Do you not see you move him? Let me alone with him.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: No way but gentleness, gently, gently. The fiend is rough, and will not be roughly us’d.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Why, how now, my bawcock? How dost thou, chuck?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Sir!

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Ay, biddy, come with me. What, man, ’tis not for gravity to play at cherry-pit with Sathan. Hang him, foul collier!

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Get him to say his prayers, good Sir Toby, get him to pray.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: My prayers, minx!

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: No, I warrant you, he will not hear of godliness.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Go hang yourselves all! You are idle shallow things, I am not of your element. You shall know more hereafter.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Is’t possible?

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: If this were play’d upon a stage now, I could condemn it as an improbable fiction.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: His very genius hath taken the infection of the device, man.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Nay, pursue him now, lest the device take air, and taint.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Why, we shall make him mad indeed.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: The house will be the quieter.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Come, we’ll have him in a dark room and bound. My niece is already in the belief that he’s mad. We may carry it thus, for our pleasure and his penance, till our very pastime, tir’d out of breath, prompt us to have mercy on him; at which time we will bring the device to the bar and crown thee for a finder of madmen. But see, but see.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: More matter for a May morning.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Here’s the challenge, read it. I warrant there’s vinegar and pepper in’t.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Is’t so saucy?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Ay, is’t! I warrant him. Do but read.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Give me.

line.RECITE: “Youth, whatsoever thou art, thou art but a scurvy fellow.”

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Good, and valiant.

line.RECITE: “Wonder not, nor admire not in thy mind, why I do call thee so, for I will show thee no reason for’t.”

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: A good note, that keeps you from the blow of the law.

line.RECITE: “Thou com’st to the Lady Olivia, and in my sight she uses thee kindly. But thou liest in thy throat, that is not the matter I challenge thee for.”

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Very brief, and to exceeding good sense—less.

line.RECITE: “I will waylay thee going home, where if it be thy chance to kill me”—

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Good.

line.RECITE: “Thou kill’st me like a rogue and a villain.”

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Still you keep o’ th’ windy side of the law; good.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.

line.RECITE: “Fare thee well, and God have mercy upon one of our souls! He may have mercy upon mine, but my hope is better, and so look to thyself. Thy friend as thou usest him, and thy sworn enemy,
Andrew Aguecheek.”

speech.line: If this letter move him not, his legs cannot. I’ll give’t him.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: You may have very fit occasion for’t; he is now in some commerce with my lady, and will by and by depart.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Go, Sir Andrew, scout me for him at the corner of the orchard like a burn-baily. So soon as ever thou seest him, draw, and as thou draw’st, swear horrible; for it comes to pass oft that a terrible oath, with a swaggering accent sharply twang’d off, gives manhood more approbation than ever proof itself would have earn’d him. Away!

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Nay, let me alone for swearing.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Now will not I deliver his letter; for the behavior of the young gentleman gives him out to be of good capacity and breeding; his employment between his lord and my niece confirms no less. Therefore this letter, being so excellently ignorant, will breed no terror in the youth; he will find it comes from a clodpole. But, sir, I will deliver his challenge by word of mouth, set upon Aguecheek a notable report of valor, and drive the gentleman (as I know his youth will aptly receive it) into a most hideous opinion of his rage, skill, fury, and impetuosity. This will so fright them both that they will kill one another by the look, like cockatrices.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Here he comes with your niece. Give them way till he take leave, and presently after him.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: I will meditate the while upon some horrid message for a challenge.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt Sir Toby, Fabian, and Maria.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: I have said too much unto a heart of stone,
And laid mine honor too unchary on’t.
There’s something in me that reproves my fault;
But such a headstrong potent fault it is
That it but mocks reproof.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: With the same havior that your passion bears
Goes on my master’s griefs.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Here, wear this jewel for me, ’tis my picture.
Refuse it not, it hath no tongue to vex you;
And I beseech you come again tomorrow.
What shall you ask of me that I’ll deny,
That honor, sav’d, may upon asking give?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Nothing but this—your true love for my master.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: How with mine honor may I give him that
Which I have given to you?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I will acquit you.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Well, come again tomorrow. Fare thee well.
A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Gentleman, God save thee!

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: And you, sir.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: That defense thou hast, betake thee to’t. Of what nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I know not; but thy intercepter, full of despite, bloody as the hunter, attends thee at the orchard-end. Dismount thy tuck, be yare in thy preparation, for thy assailant is quick, skillful, and deadly.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: You mistake, sir, I am sure; no man hath any quarrel to me. My remembrance is very free and clear from any image of offense done to any man.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: You’ll find it otherwise, I assure you; therefore, if you hold your life at any price, betake you to your guard; for your opposite hath in him what youth, strength, skill, and wrath can furnish man withal.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I pray you, sir, what is he?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: He is knight, dubb’d with unhatch’d rapier, and on carpet consideration, but he is a devil in private brawl. Souls and bodies hath he divorc’d three, and his incensement at this moment is so implacable, that satisfaction can be none but by pangs of death and sepulchre. Hob, nob, is his word; give’t or take’t.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I will return again into the house, and desire some conduct of the lady. I am no fighter. I have heard of some kind of men that put quarrels purposely on others, to taste their valor. Belike this is a man of that quirk.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Sir, no; his indignation derives itself out of a very competent injury; therefore get you on, and give him his desire. Back you shall not to the house, unless you undertake that with me which with as much safety you might answer him; therefore on, or strip your sword stark naked; for meddle you must, that’s certain, or forswear to wear iron about you.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: This is as uncivil as strange. I beseech you do me this courteous office, as to know of the knight what my offense to him is. It is something of my negligence, nothing of my purpose.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: I will do so. Signior Fabian, stay you by this gentleman till my return.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: I know the knight is incens’d against you, even to a mortal arbitrement, but nothing of the circumstance more.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I beseech you, what manner of man is he?

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Nothing of that wonderful promise, to read him by his form, as you are like to find him in the proof of his valor. He is indeed, sir, the most skillful, bloody, and fatal opposite that you could possibly have found in any part of Illyria. Will you walk towards him? I will make your peace with him if I can.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I shall be much bound to you for’t. I am one that had rather go with sir priest than sir knight. I care not who knows so much of my mettle.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Why, man, he’s a very devil, I have not seen such a firago. I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard, and all; and he gives me the stuck in with such a mortal motion that it is inevitable; and on the answer, he pays you as surely as your feet hits the ground they step on. They say he has been fencer to the Sophy.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Pox on’t, I’ll not meddle with him.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Ay, but he will not now be pacified. Fabian can scarce hold him yonder.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Plague on’t, and I thought he had been valiant, and so cunning in fence, I’d have seen him damn’d ere I’d have challeng’d him. Let him let the matter slip, and I’ll give him my horse, grey Capilet.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: I’ll make the motion. Stand here, make a good show on’t; this shall end without the perdition of souls.
Marry, I’ll ride your horse as well as I ride you.
I have his horse to take up the quarrel. I have persuaded him the youth’s a devil.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: He is as horribly conceited of him; and pants and looks pale, as if a bear were at his heels.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: There’s no remedy, sir, he will fight with you for ’s oath sake. Marry, he hath better bethought him of his quarrel, and he finds that now scarce to be worth talking of; therefore draw, for the supportance of his vow. He protests he will not hurt you.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Pray God defend me! A little thing would make me tell them how much I lack of a man.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Give ground if you see him furious.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Come, Sir Andrew, there’s no remedy, the gentleman will for his honor’s sake have one bout with you. He cannot by the duello avoid it; but he has promis’d me, as he is a gentleman and a soldier, he will not hurt you. Come on, to’t.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Pray God he keep his oath!

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I do assure you, ’tis against my will.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Put up your sword. If this young gentleman
Have done offense, I take the fault on me;
If you offend him, I for him defy you.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: You, sir? Why, what are you?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more
Than you have heard him brag to you he will.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am for you.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: O good Sir Toby, hold! Here come the officers.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: I’ll be with you anon.

scene.stagedir: Steps aside to avoid the Officers.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Pray, sir, put your sword up, if you please.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Marry, will I, sir; and for that I promis’d you, I’ll be as good as my word. He will bear you easily, and reins well.

speech.speaker: 1. OFF.
speech.line: This is the man, do thy office.

speech.speaker: 2. OFF.
speech.line: Antonio, I arrest thee at the suit of Count Orsino.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: You do mistake me, sir.

speech.speaker: 1. OFF.
speech.line: No, sir, no jot. I know your favor well,
Though now you have no sea-cap on your head.
Take him away, he knows I know him well.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I must obey.
This comes with seeking you;
But there’s no remedy, I shall answer it.
What will you do, now my necessity
Makes me to ask you for my purse? It grieves me
Much more for what I cannot do for you
Than what befalls myself. You stand amaz’d,
But be of comfort.

speech.speaker: 2. OFF.
speech.line: Come, sir, away.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I must entreat of you some of that money.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: What money, sir?
For the fair kindness you have show’d me here,
And part being prompted by your present trouble,
Out of my lean and low ability
I’ll lend you something. My having is not much;
I’ll make division of my present with you.
Hold, there’s half my coffer.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Will you deny me now?
Is’t possible that my deserts to you
Can lack persuasion? Do not tempt my misery,
Lest that it make me so unsound a man
As to upbraid you with those kindnesses
That I have done for you.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: I know of none,
Nor know I you by voice or any feature.
I hate ingratitude more in a man
Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness,
Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption
Inhabits our frail blood.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: O heavens themselves!

speech.speaker: 2. OFF.
speech.line: Come, sir, I pray you go.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Let me speak a little. This youth that you see here
I snatch’d one half out of the jaws of death,
Reliev’d him with such sanctity of love,
And to his image, which methought did promise
Most venerable worth, did I devotion.

speech.speaker: 1. OFF.
speech.line: What’s that to us? The time goes by; away!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: But O, how vild an idol proves this god!
Thou hast, Sebastian, done good feature shame.
In nature there’s no blemish but the mind;
None can be call’d deform’d but the unkind.
Virtue is beauty, but the beauteous evil
Are empty trunks o’erflourish’d by the devil.

speech.speaker: 1. OFF.
speech.line: The man grows mad, away with him! Come, come, sir.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Lead me on.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Methinks his words do from such passion fly
That he believes himself; so do not I.
Prove true, imagination, O, prove true,
That I, dear brother, be now ta’en for you!

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Come hither, knight; come hither, Fabian; we’ll whisper o’er a couplet or two of most sage saws.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: He nam’d Sebastian. I my brother know
Yet living in my glass; even such and so
In favor was my brother, and he went
Still in this fashion, color, ornament,
For him I imitate. O, if it prove,
Tempests are kind and salt waves fresh in love.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward than a hare. His dishonesty appears in leaving his friend here in necessity, and denying him; and for his cowardship, ask Fabian.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: A coward, a most devout coward, religious in it.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: ’Slid, I’ll after him again, and beat him.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Do, cuff him soundly, but never draw thy sword.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: And I do not—

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Come, let’s see the event.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: I dare lay any money ’twill be nothing yet.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Will you make me believe that I am not sent for you?

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: Go to, go to, thou art a foolish fellow,
Let me be clear of thee.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Well held out, i’ faith! No, I do not know you, nor I am not sent to you by my lady, to bid you come speak with her, nor your name is not Master Cesario, nor this is not my nose neither: nothing that is so is so.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: I prithee vent thy folly somewhere else,
Thou know’st not me.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Vent my folly! He has heard that word of some great man, and now applies it to a fool. Vent my folly! I am afraid this great lubber the world will prove a cockney. I prithee now ungird thy strangeness, and tell me what I shall vent to my lady. Shall I vent to her that thou art coming?

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: I prithee, foolish Greek, depart from me.
There’s money for thee. If you tarry longer,
I shall give worse payment.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: By my troth, thou hast an open hand. These wise men that give fools money get themselves a good report—after fourteen years’ purchase.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Now, sir, have I met you again? There’s for you.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: Why, there’s for thee, and there, and there.
Are all the people mad?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Hold, sir, or I’ll throw your dagger o’er the house.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: This will I tell my lady straight; I would not be in some of your coats for twopence.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Come on, sir, hold!

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: Nay, let him alone. I’ll go another way to work with him; I’ll have an action of battery against him, if there be any law in Illyria. Though I strook him first, yet it’s no matter for that.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: Let go thy hand.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Come, sir, I will not let you go. Come, my young soldier, put up your iron; you are well flesh’d. Come on.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: I will be free from thee.Breaks away and draws his sword.What wouldst thou now?
If thou dar’st tempt me further, draw thy sword.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: What, what? Nay then I must have an ounce or two of this malapert blood from you.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Hold, Toby, on thy life I charge thee hold!

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Madam—

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Will it be ever thus? Ungracious wretch,
Fit for the mountains and the barbarous caves,
Where manners ne’er were preach’d! Out of my sight!
Be not offended, dear Cesario.
Rudesby, be gone!
speech.stagedir: Exeunt Sir Toby, Sir Andrew, and Fabian.
speech.line: I prithee, gentle friend,
Let thy fair wisdom, not thy passion, sway
In this uncivil and unjust extent
Against thy peace. Go with me to my house,
And hear thou there how many fruitless pranks
This ruffian hath botch’d up, that thou thereby
Mayst smile at this. Thou shalt not choose but go;
Do not deny. Beshrew his soul for me,
He started one poor heart of mine, in thee.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: What relish is in this? How runs the stream?
Or I am mad, or else this is a dream.
Let fancy still my sense in Lethe steep;
If it be thus to dream, still let me sleep!

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Nay, come, I prithee. Would thou’dst be rul’d by me!

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: Madam, I will.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: O, say so, and so be!

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Nay, I prithee put on this gown and this beard, make him believe thou art Sir Topas the curate, do it quickly. I’ll call Sir Toby the whilst.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Well, I’ll put it on, and I will dissemble myself in’t, and I would I were the first that ever dissembled in such a gown. I am not tall enough to become the function well, nor lean enough to be thought a good studient; but to be said an honest man and a good house-keeper goes as fairly as to say a careful man and a great scholar. The competitors enter.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Jove bless thee, Master Parson.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Bonos dies, Sir Toby: for as the old hermit of Prague, that never saw pen and ink, very wittily said to a niece of King Gorboduc, “That that is is”; so I, being Master Parson, am Master Parson; for what is “that” but “that,” and “is” but “is”?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: To him, Sir Topas.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: What ho, I say! Peace in this prison!

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: The knave counterfeits well; a good knave.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Who calls there?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Sir Topas the curate, who comes to visit Malvolio the lunatic.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, go to my lady.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Out, hyperbolical fiend! How vexest thou this man! Talkest thou nothing but of ladies?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Well said, Master Parson.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Sir Topas, never was man thus wrong’d. Good Sir Topas, do not think I am mad; they have laid me here in hideous darkness.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Fie, thou dishonest Sathan! I call thee by the most modest terms, for I am one of those gentle ones that will use the devil himself with courtesy. Say’st thou that house is dark?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: As hell, Sir Topas.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Why, it hath bay windows transparent as barricadoes, and the clerestories toward the south north are as lustrous as ebony; and yet complainest thou of obstruction?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: I am not mad, Sir Topas, I say to you this house is dark.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Madman, thou errest. I say there is no darkness but ignorance, in which thou art more puzzled than the Egyptians in their fog.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: I say this house is as dark as ignorance, though ignorance were as dark as hell; and I say there was never man thus abus’d. I am no more mad than you are; make the trial of it in any constant question.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: What is the opinion of Pythagoras concerning wild-fowl?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: That the soul of our grandam might happily inhabit a bird.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: What think’st thou of his opinion?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: I think nobly of the soul, and no way approve his opinion.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Fare thee well. Remain thou still in darkness. Thou shalt hold th’ opinion of Pythagoras ere I will allow of thy wits, and fear to kill a woodcock lest thou dispossess the soul of thy grandam. Fare thee well.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: My most exquisite Sir Topas!

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Nay, I am for all waters.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Thou mightst have done this without thy beard and gown, he sees thee not.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: To him in thine own voice, and bring me word how thou find’st him. I would we were well rid of this knavery. If he may be conveniently deliver’d, I would he were, for I am now so far in offense with my niece that I cannot pursue with any safety this sport t’ the upshot. Come by and by to my chamber.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: “Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,
Tell me how thy lady does.”

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Fool!

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: “My lady is unkind, perdie.”

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Fool!

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: “Alas, why is she so?”

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Fool, I say!

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: “She loves another”—
Who calls, ha?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Good fool, as ever thou wilt deserve well at my hand, help me to a candle, and pen, ink, and paper. As I am a gentleman, I will live to be thankful to thee for’t.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Master Malvolio?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Ay, good fool.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Alas, sir, how fell you besides your five wits?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Fool, there was never man so notoriously abus’d; I am as well in my wits, fool, as thou art.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: But as well! Then you are mad indeed, if you be no better in your wits than a fool.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: They have here propertied me, keep me in darkness, send ministers to me, asses, and do all they can to face me out of my wits.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Advise you what you say; the minister is here.—Malvolio, Malvolio, thy wits the heavens restore! Endeavor thyself to sleep, and leave thy vain bibble babble.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Sir Topas!

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Maintain no words with him, good fellow.—Who, I, sir? Not I, sir. God buy you, good Sir Topas.—Marry, amen.—I will, sir, I will.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Fool, fool, fool, I say!

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Alas, sir, be patient. What say you, sir? I am shent for speaking to you.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Good fool, help me to some light and some paper. I tell thee I am as well in my wits as any man in Illyria.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Well-a-day that you were, sir!

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: By this hand, I am. Good fool, some ink, paper, and light; and convey what I will set down to my lady. It shall advantage thee more than ever the bearing of letter did.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I will help you to’t. But tell me true, are you not mad indeed, or do you but counterfeit?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Believe me I am not, I tell thee true.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Nay, I’ll ne’er believe a madman till I see his brains. I will fetch you light and paper and ink.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Fool, I’ll requite it in the highest degree. I prithee be gone.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I am gone, sir,
And anon, sir,
I’ll be with you again;
In a trice,
Like to the old Vice,
Your need to sustain;
Who with dagger of lath,
In his rage and his wrath,
Cries, ah, ha! To the devil;
Like a mad lad,
Pare thy nails, dad.
Adieu, goodman devil.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: This is the air, that is the glorious sun,
This pearl she gave me, I do feel’t and see’t,
And though ’tis wonder that enwraps me thus,
Yet ’tis not madness. Where’s Antonio then?
I could not find him at the Elephant,
Yet there he was, and there I found this credit,
That he did range the town to seek me out.
His counsel now might do me golden service,
For though my soul disputes well with my sense,
That this may be some error, but no madness,
Yet doth this accident and flood of fortune
So far exceed all instance, all discourse,
That I am ready to distrust mine eyes,
And wrangle with my reason that persuades me
To any other trust but that I am mad,
Or else the lady’s mad; yet if ’twere so,
She could not sway her house, command her followers,
Take and give back affairs, and their dispatch,
With such a smooth, discreet, and stable bearing
As I perceive she does. There’s something in’t
That is deceivable. But here the lady comes.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Blame not this haste of mine. If you mean well,
Now go with me, and with this holy man,
Into the chantry by; there, before him,
And underneath that consecrated roof,
Plight me the full assurance of your faith,
That my most jealous and too doubtful soul
May live at peace. He shall conceal it
Whiles you are willing it shall come to note,
What time we will our celebration keep
According to my birth. What do you say?

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: I’ll follow this good man, and go with you,
And having sworn truth, ever will be true.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Then lead the way, good father, and heavens so shine
That they may fairly note this act of mine!

scene.scenepersonae: (Clown, Fabian, Duke, Viola, Curio, Lords, Antonio, Officers, Olivia, Attendants, Priest, Sir Andrew, Sir Toby, Malvolio)

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Now as thou lov’st me, let me see his letter.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Good Master Fabian, grant me another request.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Any thing.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Do not desire to see this letter.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: This is to give a dog and in recompense desire my dog again.

scene.stagedir: Enter Duke, Viola, Curio, and Lords.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Belong you to the Lady Olivia, friends?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Ay, sir, we are some of her trappings.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: I know thee well; how dost thou, my good fellow?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Truly, sir, the better for my foes and the worse for my friends.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Just the contrary: the better for thy friends.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: No, sir, the worse.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: How can that be?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Marry, sir, they praise me, and make an ass of me. Now my foes tell me plainly I am an ass; so that by my foes, sir, I profit in the knowledge of myself, and by my friends I am abus’d; so that, conclusions to be as kisses, if your four negatives make your two affirmatives, why then the worse for my friends and the better for my foes.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Why, this is excellent.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: By my troth, sir, no; though it please you to be one of my friends.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Thou shalt not be the worse for me, there’s gold.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: But that it would be double-dealing, sir, I would you could make it another.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: O, you give me ill counsel.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Put your grace in your pocket, sir, for this once, and let your flesh and blood obey it.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Well, I will be so much a sinner to be a double-dealer. There’s another.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Primo, secundo, tertio, is a good play, and the old saying is, the third pays for all. The triplex, sir, is a good tripping measure, or the bells of Saint Bennet, sir, may put you in mind—one, two, three.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: You can fool no more money out of me at this throw. If you will let your lady know I am here to speak with her, and bring her along with you, it may awake my bounty further.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Marry, sir, lullaby to your bounty till I come again. I go, sir, but I would not have you to think that my desire of having is the sin of covetousness; but as you say, sir, let your bounty take a nap, I will awake it anon.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Here comes the man, sir, that did rescue me.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: That face of his I do remember well,
Yet when I saw it last, it was besmear’d
As black as Vulcan in the smoke of war.
A baubling vessel was he captain of,
For shallow draught and bulk unprizable,
With which such scathful grapple did he make
With the most noble bottom of our fleet,
That very envy, and the tongue of loss,
Cried fame and honor on him. What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: 1. OFF.
speech.line: Orsino, this is that Antonio
That took the Phoenix and her fraught from Candy,
And this is he that did the Tiger board,
When your young nephew Titus lost his leg.
Here in the streets, desperate of shame and state,
In private brabble did we apprehend him.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: He did me kindness, sir, drew on my side,
But in conclusion put strange speech upon me.
I know not what ’twas but distraction.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Notable pirate, thou salt-water thief!
What foolish boldness brought thee to their mercies
Whom thou in terms so bloody and so dear
Hast made thine enemies?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Orsino, noble sir,
Be pleas’d that I shake off these names you give me.
Antonio never yet was thief or pirate,
Though I confess, on base and ground enough,
Orsino’s enemy. A witchcraft drew me hither:
That most ingrateful boy there by your side
From the rude sea’s enrag’d and foamy mouth
Did I redeem; a wrack past hope he was.
His life I gave him, and did thereto add
My love, without retention or restraint,
All his in dedication. For his sake
Did I expose myself (pure for his love)
Into the danger of this adverse town,
Drew to defend him when he was beset;
Where being apprehended, his false cunning
(Not meaning to partake with me in danger)
Taught him to face me out of his acquaintance,
And grew a twenty years removed thing
While one would wink; denied me mine own purse,
Which I had recommended to his use
Not half an hour before.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: How can this be?

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: When came he to this town?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Today, my lord; and for three months before,
No int’rim, not a minute’s vacancy,
Both day and night did we keep company.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Here comes the Countess, now heaven walks on earth.
But for thee, fellow—fellow, thy words are madness.
Three months this youth hath tended upon me,
But more of that anon. Take him aside.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: What would my lord, but that he may not have,
Wherein Olivia may seem serviceable?
Cesario, you do not keep promise with me.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Madam—

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Gracious Olivia—

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: What do you say, Cesario? Good my lord—

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: My lord would speak, my duty hushes me.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: If it be aught to the old tune, my lord,
It is as fat and fulsome to mine ear
As howling after music.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Still so cruel?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Still so constant, lord.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: What, to perverseness? You uncivil lady,
To whose ingrate and unauspicious altars
My soul the faithfull’st off’rings have breath’d out
That e’er devotion tender’d! What shall I do?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Even what it please my lord, that shall become him.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Why should I not (had I the heart to do it),
Like to th’ Egyptian thief at point of death,
Kill what I love? (a savage jealousy
That sometime savors nobly), but hear me this:
Since you to non-regardance cast my faith,
And that I partly know the instrument
That screws me from my true place in your favor,
Live you the marble-breasted tyrant still.
But this your minion, whom I know you love,
And whom, by heaven I swear, I tender dearly,
Him will I tear out of that cruel eye,
Where he sits crowned in his master’s spite.
Come, boy, with me, my thoughts are ripe in mischief.
I’ll sacrifice the lamb that I do love,
To spite a raven’s heart within a dove.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: And I most jocund, apt, and willingly,
To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Where goes Cesario?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: After him I love
More than I love these eyes, more than my life,
More by all mores than e’er I shall love wife.
If I do feign, you witnesses above
Punish my life for tainting of my love!

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Ay me, detested! How am I beguil’d!

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Who does beguile you? Who does do you wrong?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Hast thou forgot thyself? Is it so long?
Call forth the holy father.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Come, away!

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Husband?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Ay, husband. Can he that deny?

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Her husband, sirrah?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: No, my lord, not I.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Alas, it is the baseness of thy fear
That makes thee strangle thy propriety.
Fear not, Cesario, take thy fortunes up,
Be that thou know’st thou art, and then thou art
As great as that thou fear’st.
O, welcome, father!
Father, I charge thee by thy reverence
Here to unfold, though lately we intended
To keep in darkness what occasion now
Reveals before ’tis ripe, what thou dost know
Hath newly pass’d between this youth and me.

speech.speaker: PRIEST.
speech.line: A contract of eternal bond of love,
Confirm’d by mutual joinder of your hands,
Attested by the holy close of lips,
Strength’ned by interchangement of your rings,
And all the ceremony of this compact
Seal’d in my function, by my testimony;
Since when, my watch hath told me, toward my grave
I have travell’d but two hours.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: O thou dissembling cub! What wilt thou be
When time hath sow’d a grizzle on thy case?
Or will not else thy craft so quickly grow,
That thine own trip shall be thine overthrow?
Farewell, and take her, but direct thy feet
Where thou and I (henceforth) may never meet.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: My lord, I do protest—

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: O, do not swear!
Hold little faith, though thou hast too much fear.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: For the love of God, a surgeon! Send one presently to Sir Toby.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: H’as broke my head across, and has given Sir Toby a bloody coxcomb too. For the love of God, your help! I had rather than forty pound I were at home.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Who has done this, Sir Andrew?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: The Count’s gentleman, one Cesario. We took him for a coward, but he’s the very devil incardinate.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: My gentleman, Cesario?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: ’Od’s lifelings, here he is! You broke my head for nothing, and that that I did, I was set on to do’t by Sir Toby.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Why do you speak to me? I never hurt you.
I drew your sword upon me without cause,
But I bespake you fair, and hurt you not.

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: If a bloody coxcomb be a hurt, you have hurt me. I think you set nothing by a bloody coxcomb. Here comes Sir Toby halting—you shall hear more. But if he had not been in drink, he would have tickled you othergates than he did.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: How now, gentleman? How is’t with you?

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: That’s all one. H’as hurt me, and there’s th’ end on’t. Sot, didst see Dick surgeon, sot?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: O, he’s drunk, Sir Toby, an hour agone; his eyes were set at eight i’ th’ morning.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Then he’s a rogue, and a passy-measures pavin. I hate a drunken rogue.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Away with him! Who hath made this havoc with them?

speech.speaker: SIR AND.
speech.line: I’ll help you, Sir Toby, because we’ll be dress’d together.

speech.speaker: SIR TO.
speech.line: Will you help?—an ass-head and a coxcomb and a knave, a thin-fac’d knave, a gull!

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Get him to bed, and let his hurt be look’d to.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt Clown, Fabian, Sir Toby, and Sir Andrew.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: I am sorry, madam, I have hurt your kinsman,
But had it been the brother of my blood,
I must have done no less with wit and safety.
You throw a strange regard upon me, and by that
I do perceive it hath offended you.
Pardon me, sweet one, even for the vows
We made each other but so late ago.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: One face, one voice, one habit, and two persons,
A natural perspective, that is and is not!

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: Antonio, O my dear Antonio!
How have the hours rack’d and tortur’d me,
Since I have lost thee!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Sebastian are you?

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: Fear’st thou that, Antonio?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: How have you made division of yourself?
An apple, cleft in two, is not more twin
Than these two creatures. Which is Sebastian?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Most wonderful!

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: Do I stand there? I never had a brother;
Nor can there be that deity in my nature
Of here and every where. I had a sister,
Whom the blind waves and surges have devour’d.
Of charity, what kin are you to me?
What countryman? What name? What parentage?

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: Of Messaline; Sebastian was my father,
Such a Sebastian was my brother too;
So went he suited to his watery tomb.
If spirits can assume both form and suit,
You come to fright us.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: A spirit I am indeed,
But am in that dimension grossly clad
Which from the womb I did participate.
Were you a woman, as the rest goes even,
I should my tears let fall upon your cheek,
And say, “Thrice welcome, drowned Viola!”

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: My father had a mole upon his brow.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: And so had mine.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: And died that day when Viola from her birth
Had numb’red thirteen years.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: O, that record is lively in my soul!
He finished indeed his mortal act
That day that made my sister thirteen years.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: If nothing lets to make us happy both
But this my masculine usurp’d attire,
Do not embrace me till each circumstance
Of place, time, fortune, do cohere and jump
That I am Viola—which to confirm,
I’ll bring you to a captain in this town,
Where lie my maiden weeds; by whose gentle help
I was preserv’d to serve this noble count.
All the occurrence of my fortune since
Hath been between this lady and this lord.

speech.speaker: SEB.
speech.line: So comes it, lady, you have been mistook;
But Nature to her bias drew in that.
You would have been contracted to a maid,
Nor are you therein, by my life, deceiv’d,
You are betroth’d both to a maid and man.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Be not amaz’d, right noble is his blood.
If this be so, as yet the glass seems true,
I shall have share in this most happy wrack.
Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times
Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: And all those sayings will I over swear,
And all those swearings keep as true in soul
As doth that orbed continent the fire
That severs day from night.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Give me thy hand,
And let me see thee in thy woman’s weeds.

speech.speaker: VIO.
speech.line: The captain that did bring me first on shore
Hath my maid’s garments. He upon some action
Is now in durance, at Malvolio’s suit,
A gentleman, and follower of my lady’s.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: He shall enlarge him; fetch Malvolio hither.
And yet, alas, now I remember me,
They say, poor gentleman, he’s much distract.
speech.stagedir: Enter Clown with a letter, and Fabian.
speech.line: A most extracting frenzy of mine own
From my remembrance clearly banish’d his.
How does he, sirrah?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Truly, madam, he holds Belzebub at the stave’s end as well as a man in his case may do. H’as here writ a letter to you; I should have given’t you today morning. But as a madman’s epistles are no gospels, so it skills not much when they are deliver’d.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Open’t and read it.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Look then to be well edified when the fool delivers the madman.

line.RECITE: “By the Lord, madam”—

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: How now, art thou mad?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: No, madam, I do but read madness. And your ladyship will have it as it ought to be, you must allow vox.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Prithee read i’ thy right wits.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: So I do, madonna; but to read his right wits is to read thus; therefore perpend, my princess, and give ear.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Read it you, sirrah.

line.RECITE: “By the Lord, madam, you wrong me, and the world shall know it. Though you have put me into darkness, and given your drunken cousin rule over me, yet have I the benefit of my senses as well as your ladyship. I have your own letter that induc’d me to the semblance I put on; with the which I doubt not but to do myself much right, or you much shame. Think of me as you please. I leave my duty a little unthought of, and speak out of my injury.
The madly-us’d Malvolio.”

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Did he write this?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Ay, madam.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: This savors not much of distraction.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: See him deliver’d, Fabian, bring him hither.
My lord, so please you, these things further thought on,
To think me as well a sister as a wife,
One day shall crown th’ alliance on’t, so please you,
Here at my house and at my proper cost.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Madam, I am most apt t’ embrace your offer.
Your master quits you; and for your service done him,
So much against the mettle of your sex,
So far beneath your soft and tender breeding,
And since you call’d me master for so long,
Here is my hand—you shall from this time be
Your master’s mistress.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: A sister! You are she.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Is this the madman?

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Ay, my lord, this same.
How now, Malvolio?

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Madam, you have done me wrong,
Notorious wrong.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Have I, Malvolio? No.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: Lady, you have. Pray you peruse that letter.
You must not now deny it is your hand;
Write from it if you can, in hand or phrase,
Or say ’tis not your seal, not your invention.
You can say none of this. Well, grant it then,
And tell me, in the modesty of honor,
Why you have given me such clear lights of favor,
Bade me come smiling and cross-garter’d to you,
To put on yellow stockings, and to frown
Upon Sir Toby and the lighter people;
And acting this in an obedient hope,
Why have you suffer’d me to be imprison’d,
Kept in a dark house, visited by the priest,
And made the most notorious geck and gull
That e’er invention play’d on? Tell me why!

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Alas, Malvolio, this is not my writing,
Though I confess much like the character;
But out of question ’tis Maria’s hand.
And now I do bethink me, it was she
First told me thou wast mad. Then cam’st in smiling,
And in such forms which here were presuppos’d
Upon thee in the letter. Prithee be content.
This practice hath most shrewdly pass’d upon thee;
But when we know the grounds and authors of it,
Thou shalt be both the plaintiff and the judge
Of thine own cause.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Good madam, hear me speak,
And let no quarrel nor no brawl to come
Taint the condition of this present hour,
Which I have wond’red at. In hope it shall not,
Most freely I confess, myself and Toby
Set this device against Malvolio here,
Upon some stubborn and uncourteous parts
We had conceiv’d against him. Maria writ
The letter at Sir Toby’s great importance,
In recompense whereof he hath married her.
How with a sportful malice it was follow’d
May rather pluck on laughter than revenge,
If that the injuries be justly weigh’d
That have on both sides pass’d.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: Alas, poor fool, how have they baffled thee!

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Why, “some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrown upon them.” I was one, sir, in this enterlude—one Sir Topas, sir, but that’s all one. “By the Lord, fool, I am not mad.” But do you remember? “Madam, why laugh you at such a barren rascal? And you smile not, he’s gagg’d.” And thus the whirligig of time brings in his revenges.

speech.speaker: MAL.
speech.line: I’ll be reveng’d on the whole pack of you.

speech.speaker: OLI.
speech.line: He hath been most notoriously abus’d.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Pursue him, and entreat him to a peace;
He hath not told us of the captain yet.
When that is known, and golden time convents,
A solemn combination shall be made
Of our dear souls. Mean time, sweet sister,
We will not part from hence. Cesario, come—
For so you shall be while you are a man;
But when in other habits you are seen,
Orsino’s mistress, and his fancy’s queen.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: When that I was and a little tiny boy,
With hey ho, the wind and the rain,
A foolish thing was but a toy,
For the rain it raineth every day.
But when I came to man’s estate,
With hey ho, etc.
’Gainst knaves and thieves men shut their gate,
For the rain, etc.
But when I came, alas, to wive,
With hey ho, etc.
By swaggering could I never thrive,
For the rain, etc.
But when I came unto my beds,
With hey ho, etc.
With toss-pots still had drunken heads,
For the rain, etc.
A great while ago the world begun,
With hey ho, etc.
But that’s all one, our play is done,
And we’ll strive to please you every day.
